Text:
@ctang, thanks for uploading that. Also delete this folder at Part 1:
/Library/Preferences/FLEXnet Publisher

A few notes additional notes to part 1 of the post:

- / is the system root folder (which you can find in Finder by clicking on the hard drive icon at devices)

- ~ is the User folder (which you can find in Finder by clicking on the home icon at places)

- You don't have to remove old installations. However, I strongly recommend to at least delete the "/Library/Application Support/FLEXnet Publisher" and "/Library/Preferences/FLEXnet Publisher" folders and re-enter the relevant serial upon opening an Adobe application. By keeping your old FLEXnet Publisher folders you may run into licensing errors.

- Obviously, if you're attached to your old Adobe application preferences, don't delete the preferences files in the system and User libraries. There is no harm in doing so, they'll be automatically regenerated but by deleting them you will loose your user preferences. I prefer to start with a clean system but that may not be the case for everybody.

* You can find the Adobe CS5 package (excluding Acrobat) on The Pirate Bay. Search for "Adobe CS5 Master Collection [MAC]"

* Download Adobe Acrobat 9 Pro (not included in the CS5 torrent). On the Demonoid website search for "Acrobat Pro 9.0 + 9.1 Update + SN".

@jlie69 I already wrote the answer to your question in my post above:
- You don't have to remove old installations and can use new and old installations side by side. However, I strongly recommend to at least delete the "/Library/Application Support/FLEXnet Publisher" and "/Library/Preferences/FLEXnet Publisher" folders and re-enter the relevant serial upon opening an Adobe application. By keeping your old FLEXnet Publisher folders you may run into licensing errors.

BUT

'Hosts' file was LOCKED. Could not edit anything. So searched google for ways to edit it.
I used 'sudo nano /etc/hosts' in terminal to edit within terminal and saved.

Then re-opened Terminal again to enter 'sudo dscacheutil -flushcache' which apparently "blocks Adobe activation servers"?

And.. Next time, Please explain what those 'Terminal' commands are executing for us newbies - so we at least have a clearer understanding. Thanks!!

I also had issues with this one. The first instructions in the terminal window didn't work for me. I followed these and I got it to work:

'Hosts' file was LOCKED. Could not edit anything. So searched google for ways to edit it.
I used 'sudo nano /etc/hosts' in terminal to edit within terminal and saved.

Editing in Terminal was interesting for me. But, once I did that, all the rest of the instructions worked for me. Thanks!

Works on Lion. However, the instructions for the Terminal are not the same. This is what I did, so I thought I'd share it with you guys. =) 

Terminal
Type this into the terminal in order to access your host files if you're using Lion:
sudo nano /private/etc/hosts

to save you need to press Ctrl X, and then Y for yes and lastly press the enter key. 

In part 3, to flush the cache in the terminal. I typed in:
sudo killall -INFO mDNSResponder 
sudo killall -HUP mDNSResponder
